verses.text: The sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: The genealogy begins with the three sons of Levi, foundational for Israel's priestly lineage. This establishes the legitimacy and sacred nature of the Levitical priesthood, which continues to play a pivotal role in mediating between God and His people.

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
verses.comment: The text highlights Kohath's sons as the line through which Moses and Aaron would come, strengthening the continuity between patriarchs and priesthood.

verses.text: The children of Amram: Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. The sons of Aaron: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.comment: Aaron and Moses are especially set apart, with Aaron's sons continuing the priestly line. The mention of Nadab and Abihu’s fate (Lev. 10:1-2) underscores the responsibilities and dangers of the priesthood.

verses.text: Eleazar fathered Phinehas, Phinehas fathered Abishua,
verses.comment: Phinehas’ zeal (Numbers 25:11-13) led to a lasting priestly covenant. The lineage traces the faithful transmission of priestly authority.

verses.text: Abishua fathered Bukki, Bukki fathered Uzzi,
verses.comment: The genealogy maintains the line’s purity and continuity even during less-recorded generations, reflecting God’s providence through obscure times.

verses.text: Uzzi fathered Zerahiah, Zerahiah fathered Meraioth,
verses.comment: These names, though little known, show the faithfulness required to preserve ordained ministry through each generation.

verses.text: Meraioth fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
verses.comment: The emphasis on father-to-son succession highlights the importance of tradition and continuous leadership in the priestly order.

verses.text: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Ahimaaz,
verses.comment: Zadok is significant as the priest who remained faithful to King David and Solomon. This integrity set the foundation for legitimate priestly authority in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Ahimaaz fathered Azariah, Azariah fathered Johanan,
verses.comment: The line is traced down through the generations, directing us to the stability and intended perpetuity of the priesthood.

verses.text: Johanan fathered Azariah, who served as priest in the house that Solomon built in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Azariah's ministry in the temple built by Solomon strengthens the continuity between Moses' covenant and Solomon's centralized worship—a model fulfilling God's plan for ordered liturgy.

verses.text: Azariah fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
verses.comment: This verse continues the faithful succession in the priestly line, marking the endurance of divinely-instituted leadership.

verses.text: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Shallum,
verses.comment: Another Zadok is named, showing recurrence of important priestly names and reaffirming significance in Israel's worship structure.

verses.text: Shallum fathered Hilkiah, Hilkiah fathered Azariah,
verses.comment: Hilkiah helped rediscover the Book of the Law during Josiah's reign, aiding national renewal through the central role of the priesthood in guiding God's people.

verses.text: Azariah fathered Seraiah, Seraiah fathered Jehozadak.
verses.comment: Jehozadak was exiled when the LORD sent Judah and Jerusalem into exile, demonstrating how priestly leadership suffers alongside the people in times of judgment.

verses.text: Jehozadak went into exile when the LORD sent Judah and Jerusalem into exile by the hand of Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.comment: The exile shows God's justice and His relentless commitment to purification and restoration of true worship, foreshadowing a future restoration.

verses.text: The sons of Levi: Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: This repetition of the Levitical lines affirms their centrality to Israel's worship, grounding authority in well-established lineage.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Gershom: Libni and Shimei.
verses.comment: Gershom’s sons become key progenitors of lines that serve in temple duties (see Num. 3:21-26).

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
verses.comment: Repeats the Kohathite line for clarity, as this family bears the high-priestly office and greatest responsibilities for sacred objects.

verses.text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their fathers.
verses.comment: The Levitical divisions assure that service in worship is diversified yet unified under God's command.

verses.text: Of Gershom: Libni, his son Jahath, his son Zimmah,
verses.comment: Detailed names reinforce hereditary tradition as essential to the stability of worship practice.

verses.text: his son Joah, his son Iddo, his son Zerah, his son Jeatherai.
verses.comment: Such genealogies shaped the qualifications for temple service, fostering accountability and order.

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amminadab, his son Korah, his son Assir,
verses.comment: Korah is remembered for leading a rebellion (Num. 16), but his line survives, showing God's mercy and the chance for redemption even after sin.

verses.text: his son Elkanah, his son Ebiasaph, his son Assir,
verses.comment: Genealogical repetition, standard to oral tradition, stresses the line's purity and continuity.

verses.text: his son Tahath, his son Uriel, his son Uzziah, his son Shaul.
verses.comment: Every name affirms the divine history intertwined through ordained ministry.

verses.text: The sons of Elkanah: Amasai and Ahimoth.
verses.comment: These lines are significant since Samuel would come from Elkanah, a prophet who intercedes as priest and judge, prefiguring Christ’s unique role as mediator.

verses.text: Elkanah’s son: Zophai; his son Nahath,
verses.comment: The names highlight the continuity within the house of Elkanah.

verses.text: his son Eliab, his son Jeroham, his son Elkanah.
verses.comment: Priestly and prophetic functions converge in these generations, hinting at the unity of spiritual and sacramental leadership.

verses.text: The sons of Samuel: Joel the firstborn and Abijah the second.
verses.comment: Samuel’s sons failed in their duties (1 Sam. 8:2–3), which launches Israel’s request for a king. This strengthens the idea that proper spiritual succession is crucial for God’s order.

verses.text: The sons of Merari: Mahli, Libni his son, Shimei his son, Uzzah his son,
verses.comment: More Levitical lines are accounted for, emphasizing the distributed responsibility in worship.

verses.text: his son Shimea, his son Haggiah, his son Asaiah.
verses.comment: The Merarite line completes the primary Levitical families, showing the completeness of God’s provision for corporate worship.

verses.text: These are the men David put in charge of music in the house of the LORD after the ark came to rest there:
verses.comment: David instituting music in worship hints at the value of ordered, sacramental worship, preparing for the transition to temple liturgy.

verses.text: They served with singing before the tabernacle of the tent of meeting, until Solomon built the house of the LORD in Jerusalem. They stood according to their order for their service.
verses.comment: Order in worship is critical and prefigures the established, perpetual liturgies that will develop in the fullness of divine worship.

verses.text: These are the men who ministered with their sons: Of the Kohathites: Heman the singer, son of Joel, son of Samuel,
verses.comment: Heman, a descendent of both prophet and priest, led music—a model for the synthesis of doctrine and music in corporate worship.

verses.text: son of Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Toah,
verses.comment: Listing ancestors situates Heman firmly in the priestly line, underlining legitimacy and tradition.

verses.text: son of Zuph, son of Elkanah, son of Mahath, son of Amasai,
verses.comment: The chain of names solidifies the integrity of succession through generations.

verses.text: son of Elkanah, son of Joel, son of Azariah, son of Zephaniah,
verses.comment: These names interlink earlier genealogies, showing both unity and variety within one priestly order.

verses.text: son of Tahath, son of Assir, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah,
verses.comment: Even the descendants of rebels are restored to ministry, reflecting God’s mercy and calling.

verses.text: son of Izhar, son of Kohath, son of Levi, son of Israel.
verses.comment: The genealogy rightly ends at Levi and Israel, affirming the patriarchal and tribal roots of the priesthood.

verses.text: And his brother Asaph, who stood at his right hand: Asaph son of Berechiah, son of Shimea,
verses.comment: Asaph, equally esteemed, provides a second priestly musical line, strengthening the concept of collegial ministry.

verses.text: son of Michael, son of Baaseiah, son of Malchijah,
verses.comment: Lineages continue to reinforce the authenticity and continuity appointed by God.

verses.text: son of Ethni, son of Zerah, son of Adiah,
verses.comment: Further legitimizes worship, showing how music and word together serve the temple liturgy.

verses.text: son of Ethan, son of Zimmah, son of Shimei,
verses.comment: These are sons of Levi by a separate branch, affirming that multiple lines serve cooperatively.

verses.text: son of Jahath, son of Gershon, son of Levi.
verses.comment: Asaph’s line is traced to Gershon, ensuring his service is both legitimate and connected to God’s original design for worship.

verses.text: Of the sons of Merari, their brothers, on the left hand: Ethan the son of Kishi, son of Abdi, son of Malluch,
verses.comment: Ethan represents a third musical-accompaniment line, demonstrating the divinely-willed variety within ordered worship.

verses.text: son of Hashabiah, son of Amaziah, son of Hilkiah,
verses.comment: This depth of genealogy guarantees proper status and role for each minister.

verses.text: son of Amzi, son of Bani, son of Shamer,
verses.comment: The thorough recording insists upon accountability and tradition in ministry.

verses.text: son of Mahli, son of Mushi, son of Merari, son of Levi.
verses.comment: Ethan’s lineage completes the triad of Levitical worship leadership, rooted all the way in Levi.

verses.text: And their brothers the Levites were appointed to all the service of the tabernacle of the house of God.
verses.comment: The Levites’ broad role points to a holistic system of service in God’s house, a type for spiritual ministry in the new covenant.

verses.text: But Aaron and his sons made offerings on the altar of burnt offering and on the altar of incense, for all the work of the Most Holy Place, to make atonement for Israel, as Moses the servant of God commanded.
verses.comment: Aaron’s unique priesthood is distinct among Levites, prefiguring the high priestly offerings fulfilled in Christ (see Heb. 9:11-14).

verses.text: These are the sons of Aaron: Eleazar, his son Phinehas, his son Abishua,
verses.comment: Genealogy restated as proof of unbroken priestly line—a condition for legitimate sacrifice and worship.

verses.text: his son Bukki, his son Uzzi, his son Zerahiah,
verses.comment: Stresses the same lineage as earlier, outlining continuity, central for Old Covenant liturgy.

verses.text: his son Meraioth, his son Amariah, his son Ahitub,
verses.comment: These transitions stand for reliability in transmitting sacred tradition.

verses.text: his son Zadok, his son Ahimaaz.
verses.comment: Zadok's priesthood continues to symbolize faithfulness and unbroken succession, crucial in the renewal of Jerusalem's faith.

verses.text: Now these are their dwelling places according to their settlements within their borders. To the sons of Aaron, of the families of the Kohathites, for theirs was the first lot,
verses.comment: The division of land underscores God's provision for His ministers, allowing them stability and support to serve the people in spiritual matters.

verses.text: they gave them Hebron in the land of Judah and its surrounding pasturelands.
verses.comment: Providing cities with surrounding land for the priests fulfilled the command to support worship and teaching ministries.

verses.text: But the fields of the city and its villages, they gave to Caleb the son of Jephunneh.
verses.comment: While priests had towns, Caleb was rewarded for faithfulness with the fields, showing a balance of reward for both spiritual and civic virtue.

verses.text: To the sons of Aaron they gave Hebron, the city of refuge, Libnah with its pasturelands, Jattir, Eshtemoa with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Cities of refuge, entrusted to priests, manifest God’s care for both justice and mercy, foreshadowing the Church as a sanctuary for all who seek forgiveness.

verses.text: Hilen with its pasturelands, Debir with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Priestly cities distributed in Judah root worship and doctrine in every tribe, enhancing unity in faith.

verses.text: Ashan with its pasturelands, and Beth-shemesh with its pasturelands.
verses.comment: Beth-shemesh becomes a prominent priestly town, later featuring in key biblical events.

verses.text: And from the tribe of Benjamin: Geba, Alemeth, and Anathoth, with their pasturelands. All their cities throughout their families were thirteen.
verses.comment: Thirteen towns provide for the needs of the priests, paralleling the fullness of their service throughout Israel.

verses.text: To the rest of the children of Kohath were granted by lot, out of the family of the tribe of Ephraim, from the tribe of Dan, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh, ten cities.
verses.comment: The division of cities by lot reflects God’s sovereignty in assigning ministries and resources.

verses.text: To the sons of Gershom, according to their families, out of the tribe of Issachar, from the tribe of Asher, from the tribe of Naphtali, and from the tribe of Manasseh in Bashan, thirteen cities.
verses.comment: Multiplying ministry locations fosters a universal principle of the need for spiritual life in all regions, not just a spiritual elite.

verses.text: To the sons of Merari, according to their families, out of the tribe of Reuben, from the tribe of Gad, and from the tribe of Zebulun, twelve cities.
verses.comment: The dispersal affirms that spiritual teaching and access to God's presence are meant for the whole people.

verses.text: The people of Israel gave to the Levites these cities with their pasturelands.
verses.comment: The collective support of Levites reflects Israel's corporate responsibility for ongoing worship.

verses.text: They gave by lot, out of the tribe of the families of the children of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin these cities, whose names are listed by name.
verses.comment: Liturgical and priestly life is embedded in, not separate from, local community—an important Old Testament priority.

verses.text: Some of the families of the sons of Kohath had cities of their territory out of the tribe of Ephraim.
verses.comment: Kohathite influence extends farther, showing God’s will for constructive presence in multiple areas.

verses.text: They gave them the cities of refuge: Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim with its pasturelands, Gezer with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Shechem, a sacred city from Abraham’s time (Gen. 12:6-7), becomes a refuge, anticipating Christ’s mercy and the safety of God’s house.

verses.text: Jokmeam with its pasturelands, Beth-horon with its pasturelands,
Aijalon with its pasturelands, Gath-rimmon with its pasturelands,
and out of the half-tribe of Manasseh, Aner with its pasturelands, and Bileam with its pasturelands, for the rest of the families of the sons of Kohath.
verses.comment: The blessings of ministry are distributed even beyond the Jordan and into the next generation.

verses.text: To the sons of Gershom out of the half-tribe of Manasseh: Golan in Bashan with its pasturelands and Ashtaroth with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: The network of cities secures teaching and support of God’s people in all places.

verses.text: and out of the tribe of Issachar: Kedesh with its pasturelands, Daberath with its pasturelands,
Ramoth with its pasturelands, Anem with its pasturelands,
out of the tribe of Asher: Mashal with its pasturelands, Abdon with its pasturelands,
Hukok with its pasturelands, Rehob with its pasturelands,
and out of the tribe of Naphtali: Kedesh in Galilee with its pasturelands, Hammon with its pasturelands, Kiriathaim with its pasturelands.
verses.comment: Kedesh in Galilee will later be significant in Jesus’ ministry area, foreshadowing the extension of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: To the rest—the sons of Merari—were given out of the tribe of Zebulun: Rimmono with its pasturelands, Tabor with its pasturelands;
verses.comment: Tabor, the mountain, is depicted in later salvation history (as in the Transfiguration, Matt. 17:1–8), providing subtle typological resonance.

verses.text: and across the Jordan from Jericho, east of the Jordan, out of the tribe of Reuben: Bezer in the wilderness with its pasturelands, Jahzah with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Bezer as a city of refuge speaks again to God’s mercy, anticipating Christ’s redemptive sanctuary for all sinners.

verses.text: Kedemoth with its pasturelands, and Mephaath with its pasturelands;
and out of the tribe of Gad: Ramoth in Gilead with its pasturelands, Mahanaim with its pasturelands,
Heshbon with its pasturelands, and Jazer with its pasturelands.
verses.comment: This formal closure on the distribution of Levitical cities supports the notion that worship and service are gifts given by God for the good of the whole people, pointing ahead to ministry in the universal Church.
